awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: EarthCube Integration: Accelerating Scientific workflowS using EarthCube Technologies (ASSET)
awd_abstract_narration:
A major need in the geosciences is to reduce the amount of time geoscientists spend on "data wrangling" tasks (finding, accessing, subsetting, gridding, processing, reformatting, visualizing) so that they can spend more time on complex scientific analysis. This project will develop a means for scientists to document and interact with all of the data management and analysis tools that they need to create a scientific result, and it will add tools to find common patterns in their work to help find tools that could reduce the time needed to produce the result. This work may also help to make moethods and analyses more transparent by providing the means to track the steps in creating a scientific result.

This project builds on relationships among cyberinfrastructure experts and geoscientists examine current scientific workflows and the integration of EarthCube tools.  The work will include a workflow sketching interface to specify the steps, dependencies, current tools, current duration, and other important aspects of a scientist's workflow.  As part of the proposed pilot project, the team will examine two geoscience use cases (hurricane risk and water resources) in detail and assign cyberinfrastructure experts to integrate EarthCube tools into these science workflows, to demonstrate the increases in productivity that are realized.  In addition, the team will conduct a workshop/clinic at a major geoscience conference to collect additional use cases from the community, where geoscientists will describe their workflows and receive personalized advice on the use of EarthCube tools.  If successful, the researchers may expand on this pilot project to conduct many more workshops at other venues and to map many more scientific workflows to corresponding EarthCube technologies.

por.por_cntn:
A major driver of EarthCube has always been to significantly reduce the amount of time geoscientists spend on "data wrangling" tasks (finding, accessing, sub-setting, gridding, processing, reformatting, visualizing) so that they can spend more time on complex scientific analysis. Since EarthCube's inception, highly advanced tools and technologies have been developed, but in many cases they have not seen broad use across science domains. In part, this is due to a knowledge gap in which the cyberinfrastructure experts are keenly aware of how tools could benefit scientists and dramatically improve their productivity, but scientists may lack awareness or are often disconnected from the technical details of what the relevant tools are and how to integrate them into their science workflows.

ASSET has been designed to bridge these gaps and build strong, sustainable relationships among cyberinfrastructure experts and geoscientists through an informed and collaborative examination of their current workflows and the integration of EarthCube tools.

ASSET was funded as a pilot project, and this meant that activities were scaled back from those that were originally proposed to focus more on a proof-of-concept. Despite this, the ASSET project engaged in several major activities and achieved a number of important goals, such as:

1. Detailed analysis/profiling of 2 specific science projects as use cases and mapping of some tasks to appropriate EarthCube technologies to reduce the "time to science".

2. Development of the ASSET Workflow Sketching Tool that allows users to "diagram" all the steps in a particular workflow and associate some of them with EarthCube technologies. See: https://www.asset-project.info/sketching.html

3. Development of a prototype system for matching user workflow requirements to the most relevant EarthCube technologies and projects.

4. Hosting of several ASSET training workshops or clinics to help attendees better understand and diagram their own scientific workflows and to share best practices. The global, COVID-19 also occurred during the time period of this project which meant that meant that several of the workshops/clinics had to be virtual.

- June 2018, ASSET breakout session, EarthCube All Hand Meeting, Alexandria

- August 2018, First ASSET workshop, NCAR, 30 participants, Workflow Analysis Questionnaire

- February 2020, ASSET workshop, engaged the CZO community.

- June 2020, virtual ASSET workshop, EarthCube Virtual Annual Meeting, well- attended.

- March 2021, virtual ASSET workshop, 20+ attendees, very well-reviewed.

In conclusion, the ASSET pilot project created tools to help geoscience researchers diagram and understand their computational workflows, making it easier to share them with colleagues and to identify EarthCube technologies that could make their workflows more efficient.
